channel.title: Not all RAM Usable
channel.description:
I have a Dell Inspiron 6000 dual-booting WinXP and Win7. WinXP only uses 2GB RAM so I was not concerned until after I installed Win7. It turns out my BIOS is actually limiting the RAM that the computer can use. Here are some screenshots so you can see better of what I am talking about.
I know this one says HP, but its because my moronic friend decided to mod the OEM the windows used. [img]http://i28.tinypic.com/fmugwo.png[/img]
PC Usage is actually very high right here, its normally at 23%, so don't try to tell me my processor is too low, because it runs fine. [img]http://i31.tinypic.com/dqkb5i.png[/img]
EDIT - Sorry, forgot to mention what I was posting for. I was wondering if anybody knew of a BIOS mod that would allow me to use more RAM.

item.title: Not all RAM Usable

i bought this dog with fleas and it has fleas wow can’t believe it

item.title: Not all RAM Usable
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

[quote=“mwiebelhaus, post:51, topic:352183”][quote author=Niall link=topic=448537.msg3294760#msg3294760 date=1280868816]

They make very cheap expensive, super quiet, somewhat reliable consumer level PC’s… what’s shit about that?

Fixed.

Seriously though I bought a dell dimension a few years back and the airflow was so bad the fans would be really really loud when I did anything remotely cpu intensive, it wasn’t cheap, came loaded with quite a lot of crap and bla bla bla.

When I built this pc an equivalent dell was 150%(!!!) more expensive.

Nialls current PC (Explains Airflow Problems LOL):
[img]http://i31.tinypic.com/97oghh.jpg[/ img]

Does that LOOK like a motherfucking dell? That’s my pc I built last year, and runs half as hot under prime95(in its current state) than the dell after being recently cleaned, running idle…

No, 4gb is (roughly) the amount that can exist on one page using 32-bit addressing. Each process can still use a different page, so having over 4gb is still perfectly useful (with PAE) as long as no /one process/ wants more than 4gb of ram, which is pretty rare really isn’t it.[/quote]

That’s pretty fucking sexy to know.

[quote]Nialls current PC[/quote][/quote]niall said his dell had airflow problems, so you posted a picture of his computer and stated that the image explains his airflow problems… that kind of implies that you thought that computer was a dell, which it wasnt.

Read full topic

Mopman:

No, 4gb is (roughly) the amount that can exist on one page using 32-bit addressing. Each process can still use a different page, so having over 4gb is still perfectly useful (with PAE) as long as no /one process/ wants more than 4gb of ram, which is pretty rare really isn’t it.

That’s pretty fucking sexy to know.

Read full topic

item.title: Not all RAM Usable
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

I was trying to keep it simple for him. To get technical about it, 4GB is the max amount of RAM any x86 (32-bit intel) operating system can directly support at any one given time. Linux can support more with a 32-bit OS, but it basically just swaps which sticks it uses at any given time and hides this hackery from the rest of the system. So it’s still best just to use a 64-bit OS when wanting to use over 4gb of RAM.

No, 4gb is (roughly) the amount that can exist on one page using 32-bit addressing. Each process can still use a different page, so having over 4gb is still perfectly useful (with PAE) as long as no /one process/ wants more than 4gb of ram, which is pretty rare really isn’t it.

For some reason Microsoft in their infinite wisdom limited most of the consumer editions of Windows to 4gb, though. Linux is fine, as are the server editions (even Win2k supports 128gb, iirc :/)

EDIT: Ok Win2k was 32, 2003 was 128.

Read full topic

item.title: Not all RAM Usable
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:10, topic:352183”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=448537.msg3291529#msg3291529 date=1280631257]
The motherboard in that PC only supports 2gb ram.
[/quote]
Sad sad day when they actually limit this on the motherboard. I was aware of this possibility, but as for Dell, they also tell me “Your customer service ended in 2006, goodbye”. So I am trying to diagnose all possibilities of overriding this so I know for sure.[/quote]

It’s not that the mobo manufacturer limited the amount of RAM, it’s just all the hardware they chose to use will support.

[quote=“Mopman, post:15, topic:352183”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=448537.msg3291534#msg3291534 date=1280631515]
Also a 32-bit operating system can only use 4GB of RAM
[/quote]

32-bit consumer editions of Windows*[/quote]

I was trying to keep it simple for him. To get technical about it, 4GB is the max amount of RAM any x86 (32-bit intel) operating system can directly support at any one given time. Linux can support more with a 32-bit OS, but it basically just swaps which sticks it uses at any given time and hides this hackery from the rest of the system. So it’s still best just to use a 64-bit OS when wanting to use over 4gb of RAM.

Read full topic

Circut Board Info:
Board: Dell Inc. 0W9260
Serial Number: .H1HCT71.CN1296156Q7450.
Bus Clock: 133 megahertz
BIOS: Dell Inc. A09 09/28/2005

System Model:
Dell Inc. Inspiron 6000
System Service Tag: H1HCT71
Chassis Serial Number: H1HCT71
Enclosure Type: Portable

Used this program from Belarc to get even that, since all info on the bottom of this laptop is warn mostly off. I will get the link for the laptop as soon as i can, but as for now, my internet is running very slow.
